Detailed Description

PostgreSQL connectivity class.

Definition at line 1198 of file CMPostgreSQL.php.

availableMethods (  ) 

Class methods available implemented class. 

 $features = $dbh->availableMethods();
 if(in_array($features, 'getDatabaseTables'))
   $q = $dbh->getDatabaseTables();
 else echo "Uh-oh, getDatabaseTables() has not been implemented for {$dbh->engine()}";

Implements CMDatabaseProtocol.

bindValues ( $  sql,
$  values = false,
$  a = false 
)

Use internally by query() and insert() for substituting values. 

 select * from mytable where id=? and name=?

to 

 select * from mytable where id='3' and name='Bob'
Parameters:
$sql SQL
$values An array of values to bind to $sql.
$a An associative array of server options for the query.

Definition at line 472 of file CMPostgreSQL.php.

castSafeValue ( $  value,
$  col 
) [private]

Cast PostgreSQL safe type.

PostgreSQL is very strict with its typing, this will make sure the SQL type matches the type PostgreSQL wants.

Parameters:
$value Value to make safe.
$col Associative array of column information.
Returns:
Escapes type-safe value.

Definition at line 521 of file CMPostgreSQL.php.

CMPostgreSQL ( $  uri,
$  a = false 
)

Connect to a PostgreSQL database.

Database connections are made with a URI in the child class constructor like; 

 $dbh = new CMPostgreSQL("postgresql://root:password@localhost/db");
 $dbh = new CMPostgreSQL("postgres://root:password@localhost/db");
Throws a CMError Warning
See CMError::throwWarning(). If the connection could not be made.
Parameters:
$uri Connection URI.
$a An associative array of server options when connecting.

Definition at line 672 of file CMPostgreSQL.php.

dropAllTables ( $  a = array()  ) 

Drop all of the tables in the current database.

Note:
BE CAREFUL. This cannot be undone and will destory all the tables and the data they contain in an entire database.
Parameters:
$a Options. Ignored.
Returns:
true if all the tables were dropped successfully, otherwise false.

Definition at line 1171 of file CMPostgreSQL.php.

dropTable ( $  tablename,
$  a = array() 
)

Drop (delete) a table.

Use this will caution, this is irreversible.

Parameters:
$tablename The name of the table to be dropped.
$a 'cascade' can be true or false. If it is not supplied then true is used. If 'cascade' is true it will remove any objects related directly to the table likw sequences, indexes, etc.
Returns:
true on success, otherwise false.

Definition at line 1151 of file CMPostgreSQL.php.

Returns:
"PostgreSQL"

Implements CMDatabaseProtocol.

Definition at line 682 of file CMPostgreSQL.php.

eraseTable ( $  tableName  ) 

Erase (not truncate) a table.

Erasing a table removes all the entries of the table without affecting the sequences It is effectivly: 

 DELETE FROM $tableName WHERE 1;
Exceptions:
Warning If the query was unsuccessful.
Parameters:
$tableName The name of the table.
Returns:
true for success, otherwise false (such as if the table doesn't exist or you do not have adequate privileges.)
See also:
truncateTable()

Implements CMDatabaseProtocol.

Definition at line 791 of file CMPostgreSQL.php.

escapeEntity ( $  str  ) 

Escape an entity based on the correct rules of the database engine.

An entity is a table name, view name, column name, etc. Most databases require a different quote encapsulation than escapeString().

Parameters:
$str The value to be escaped.
Returns:
Escaped entity which includes and quotes or encapsulation.

Implements CMDatabaseProtocol.

Definition at line 1190 of file CMPostgreSQL.php.

escapeString ( $  str  ) 

Escape a string based on the correct rules of the database engine.

Parameters:
$str The value to be escaped.
Returns:
Escaped string that does not include surrounding quotes.

Implements CMDatabaseProtocol.

Definition at line 1064 of file CMPostgreSQL.php.

getClientEncoding (  ) 

Gets the client encoding.

PostgreSQL supports automatic character set conversion between server and client for certain character sets. getClientEncoding() returns the client encoding as a string. The returned string will be one of the standard PostgreSQL encoding identifiers.

Returns:
The client encoding, or false on error.

Definition at line 939 of file CMPostgreSQL.php.

Get the database name.

Returns the name of the database for this connection.

Returns:
A string containing the name of the database the connection is to, or false on error.

Definition at line 616 of file CMPostgreSQL.php.

getTTY (  ) 

Return the TTY name associated with the connection.

getTTY() returns the TTY name that server side debugging output is sent to on the given PostgreSQL connection resource.

Note:
getTTY() is obsolete, since the server no longer pays attention to the TTY setting, but the function remains for backwards compatibility.
Returns:
A string containing the debug TTY of the connection, or false on error.

Definition at line 1020 of file CMPostgreSQL.php.

insert ( $  name,
$  kv = false,
$  a = false 
)

INSERT statement

This uses a key-value paired array to construct an INSERT statement like:

 $dbh->insert('mytable', array('a' => 'Something', 'b' => 123.45));

Will produce and execute the following SQL: 

 insert into mytable (a, b) values ('Something', '123.45')
Throws a CMError Warning
See CMError::throwWarning(). If the query failed. 'sql' attribute contains the original SQL.
Parameters:
$name The name of the table.
$kv Associative array of fields and data.
$a Extra options.

Implements CMDatabaseProtocol.

Definition at line 573 of file CMPostgreSQL.php.

loadSQLFile ( $  path,
$  a = array() 
)

Load a SQL file into the current connection.

This will read the input file one command at a time (skipping comments) and execute the statements. If a statement fails an error will be pushed but the loading will not stop. You can review all of the errors after it's complete with isErrors() and errors().

As one command is loaded in at a time this will work on very large SQL files.

Parameters:
$path The relative or absolute path to the SQL file. The file does not have to have a .sql extension and can even be remote through a URI that PHP's fopen() can understand.
$a Associative array of options.
Returns:
true if ALL the statements executed successfully, otherwise false. Will also return false is the input file could not be opened.

Implements CMDatabaseProtocol.

Definition at line 1083 of file CMPostgreSQL.php.

Definition at line 729 of file CMPostgreSQL.php.

setAutoCommit ( $  mode = false  ) 

Turn autocommit on/off.

By default this is off. When turning off auto commit you will have to manually commit the transaction with commit() or undo with rollback().

Warning:
Changing auto commit from off to on will not commit or rollback the current transaction. If you are using a transaction make sure you COMMIT or ROLLBACK before you change the auto committing status.
Throws a CMError Warning
See CMError::throwWarning(). If a new transaction cannot begin.
Parameters:
$mode true or false.
Returns:
Always true.
See also:
commit()
rollback()

Implements CMDatabaseProtocol.

Definition at line 760 of file CMPostgreSQL.php.

setClientEncoding ( $  encoding  ) 

Set the client encoding.

setClientEncoding() sets the client encoding and returns 0 if success or -1 if error.

PostgreSQL will automatically convert data in the backend database encoding into the frontend encoding.

Parameters:
$encoding The required client encoding. One of SQL_ASCII, EUC_JP, EUC_CN, EUC_KR, EUC_TW, UNICODE, MULE_INTERNAL, LATINX (X=1...9), KOI8, WIN, ALT, SJIS, BIG5 or WIN1250. The exact list of available encodings depends on your PostgreSQL version, so check your PostgreSQL manual for a more specific list.
Returns:
Returns 0 on success or -1 on error.

Definition at line 628 of file CMPostgreSQL.php.

truncateTable ( $  tableName  ) 

TRUNCATE table.

truncateTable() uses the TRUNCATE statement with the default PostgreSQL settings. It is effectivly: 

 TRUNCATE TABLE $tableName;
Throws a CMError Warning
See CMError::throwWarning(). If the query was unsuccessful.
Parameters:
$tableName The name of the table.
Returns:
true for success, otherwise false (such as if the table doesn't exist or you do not have adequate privileges.)

Implements CMDatabaseProtocol.
